p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff; font-weight: bold;

div.p: Cited in 81-08-19 fn 1, which will need updating
GRG 19/391, State Records of South Australia, Adelaide.

p.seg: Bei Escape Cliff kommt eine grossfrüchtige Eugenia vor. Kennen Sie diese?

div.p:
A Eugenia with large fruit occurs at Escape Cliff.
NT. MS is an undated fragment. It cannot be dated on the basis of the collecting date of the specimen with the record number 175. Holtze did not use a single sequence of specimen numbers so that there are often quite different species associated with the same number sent at different times. There are four M. Holtze specimens of this species (under the current name Lindernia) in AVH (accessed 9 January 2023); two are undated and one is dated to 1882. It is possible that the fragment was included with M to M. Holtze, 19 August 1881, a request for specimens of a palm from Escape Cliff, and it is dated to 1881 on that basis, but it is a very uncertain date. Do you know it?

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; font-size: 10pt; break-before: page; font-weight: bold;

p.seg: chased up Holtze's Vandellia specimen numbered 175. The following with Maurice Holtze’s number 175 in MEL according to AVH:

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;

p.seg: all three recorded as Lindernia lobelioides, the name by which the species is now known (as recombined by M in B83.03.04, p.97)

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;

p.seg: The only other Holtze 175 is from
W
. Holtze, Hakea arborescens, 1894

It would be useful to see what was in the labels of these specimens, as on the face of it the Genus was re-assigned during the writing of the Census, and if, but a big if, M was consistent in his informal writing and his publications, it would date the fragment to 1882 or earlier. MEL 0287198 is the most critical in this regard: does M’s label call it Lindernia? If he does, it's useful, if he doesn’t it's not very definitive.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;

div.p: Also searched the Holtze letters for references to Vandellia:

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;

div.p: 82-10-00a-final. Where it is also numbered 175; dating not absolute, but not too bad.

p.seg: 89-00-00jHoltze: no rationale for date given; Vandellia is there as number 173, but when searching AVH for Holtze No. 173, found is a Vandellia (under Lindernia aplectra), dated to 1894, but with
W
Holtze as collector. The Maurice Holtze 173s are two specimens of Grewia retusifolia one collected 1882, the other 1883, which is what is recorded against that number in 82-10-00a-final.
References in Holtze letters to Lindernia:
90-10-00c-draft where Lindernia subulata is No. 1139. Once again I have nit checked out the dating rationale, but on the face of it seems more or less plausible.
89-00-00Holtze696 No dating rationale, Lindernia
crustacea as No. 689
90-10-00a 1106 Lindernia is No. 1112; once again I have not checked out the dating rationale.
89-03-00 Holtze839 Lindernia is No. 830; no dating rationale, though there is a cross reference in the list that will need to be checked out.

So, I think it will be possible to get a better dating, probably 1882 or 1883, depending on what collection dates re around for the numbers on the other lists, but its not a job to do until I’ve completed the text for the Muelleria version of the Bibliography: I've now added the URLs to the first 2056 entries, that is if a version is available, 65.9% of the entries.
For the moment I think we leave
81-00-00g where
it is, but I've put a warning progress note in place so we don’t finalise it accidentally. The aberrant naming will also act as a warning.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold;

p.seg: An impressive result from your search. I'll check out M's specimen labels, next time I go to the Herbarium.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; color: #000000; font-size: 10pt;
